citation.article-title: Emended description of the genus Glycomyces and description of Glycomyces algeriensis sp. nov., Glycomyces arizonensis sp. nov. and Glycomyces lechevalierae sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of the genus Glycomyces Labeda et al. 1985
Glycomyces [Gly′co.my.ces. Gr. adj. glykus sweet; Gr. n. myke fungus; N.L. n. Glycomyces sweet (glycolipid-containing)].
Vegetative mycelia are branching (diameter approximately 0·35–0·40 μm); aerial mycelia may be produced on certain growth media.
Oval, spherical or rod-like spores may be formed on the vegetative hyphae in some species; chains of square-ended conidia may be produced on aerial hyphae.
Type II cell wall composition (meso-diaminopimelic acid and glycine) and whole cell sugar pattern consisting of ribose, xylose, mannose and galactose.
Type PI phospholipid pattern with significant amounts of phosphatidylinositol mannosides.
The menaquinones present predominantly contain 10, 11 and/or 12 isoprene units, but the degree of saturation varies within each species.
The type species is Glycomyces harbinensis.
